info.headline: Extreme Fire Danger issued January 31 at 3:52AM MST by NWS Sioux Falls
info.description: .DISCUSSION... Issued at 438 AM CST Mon Jan 31 2022 Unseasonably warm air develops across south central South Dakota today just ahead of an approaching sfc low. Temperatures are likely to peak near 60 degrees late this afternoon in this area. Further northeast, temperatures will be notably cooler, especially in areas where snow cover lingers. Confidence is high in increasing southwest winds gusting up to 30 mph and an area of very dry air wrapping in near and south of the Missouri River Valley, which will lead to critical fire weather conditions this afternoon. Converted the previous Fire Weather Watch to a Red Flag Warning where the driest air is likely to reside. Also added Brule and Aurora counties. These and Yankton county will be on the fringes of the driest and warmest air but seem likely to still drop to critical levels. There is lingering uncertainty regarding how low dew points will fall late this afternoon across portions of south central South Dakota. Overnight HRRR and RAP runs have dew points mixing into the single digits in Gregory county, which would be even drier than is currently forecast. Trended cautiously toward this drier hi-res guidance in the current forecast, sitting drier (near or below 50th percentile) and notably warmer (near or above 75th percentile) than average model guidance. RH values will begin to rise around sunset as temperatures fall, though gusty winds will continue this evening and overnight behind a passing front. Will continue to monitor moisture and heating trends through the morning for any minor adjustments needing to be made. People are urged to exercise extreme care with respect to outdoor activities that could cause grass fires. Report new fires quickly to the nearest fire department or law enforcement office. ...EXTREME FIRE DANGER... The Grassland Fire Danger Index will reach the extreme category this afternoon. Extreme weather conditions and very low moisture content of grasses, and other dry organic material on the ground, indicate that critical burning conditions exist. All fires have the potential to become large and spread quickly, becoming erratic with extreme behavioral characteristics. No outdoor burning should take place. OUTLOOK FOR TUESDAY AFTERNOON...The Grassland Fire Danger Index will reach the very high category. The grassland fire danger product reflects fire danger for native grasses. It is not intended for cured agricultural crops, nor will it reflect conditions in road ditches which have been mowed.
